title: The Best Subject Lines for a Thank You Email After an Interview

steps.title: Offer a general, polite thank you.
steps.content: Offer a general, polite thank you. You don’t have to overcomplicate your subject line, especially if you’re in a hurry or stressed out about the whole thing. There’s nothing wrong with a simple thank you; your interviewer will understand the purpose of the email easily enough. You can also thank them for meeting with you, talking, chatting, and so on. [1] X Research source Sample email subject lines: Thank you for meeting with me! Thanks for your time today Thank you for a great interview I enjoyed meeting with you! Thank you for the opportunity! Thank you for talking to me today!

steps.title: Include the date of the job interview.
steps.content: Include the date of the job interview. This is a good idea if you don’t follow up with a thank-you email the same day as the interview. Hiring managers tend to hold multiple interviews over a few days or even weeks, so including the date can help jog their memory before they even open the email. It’ll also encourage them to respond to you faster. [2] X Research source Sample email subject lines: Thank you for your time (Interview on Sept. 5) Thank you for the interview on Friday It was great to speak with you on Wednesday!

steps.title: Specify the position that you interviewed for.
steps.content: Specify the position that you interviewed for. A hiring manager may also be interviewing for different positions. By specifying the one you want, you can remind them of your interview, clarify what the email is about, and show the interviewer that the email is an important one. Just make sure you’re using the official position title used by that company! [3] X Research source Sample email subject lines: Thank you for speaking with me about the editorial assistant position! Thank you for considering me as your new quality assurance specialist. Thank you: Marketing Manager interview with ABCD-Company.

steps.title: Personalize the subject line with your interviewer’s name.
steps.content: Personalize the subject line with your interviewer’s name. This is an easy way to get the interviewer’s attention and build a little extra rapport, even after the interview itself. Be sure to use the name that the interviewer uses themselves—and if you’re not sure, check an email from them to see how they introduce themselves or sign off. [4] X Research source Sample email subject lines: Thanks for meeting with me, Noah! Thanks so much for your time, Janice Thank you for a great interview, Kim!

steps.title: Add a detail from the interview.
steps.content: Add a detail from the interview. In your subject line, briefly reference something you and your interviewer discussed. This can help remind them about one of the better moments in the interview and show them it was memorable for you, too. In short, it can make you stand out from the crowd a bit more. [5] X Research source Sample email subject lines: Thanks for the great chat about marketing and latte flavors! Thank you for sharing your accounting advice!

steps.title: Ask the interviewer a question in the subject line.
steps.content: Ask the interviewer a question in the subject line. Interviewers don’t always reply to thank you emails—so if you want to encourage a reply, try putting a question right in the subject line. It’ll grab their attention and demonstrate your interest in the job; it may even boost your chances of getting the job. Try asking a question about the job or see if you can get feedback from them. Sample email subject lines: Thank you for the interview! Need anything else? Great to meet you! More work samples needed? Thanks for meeting with me. Do you have any feedback? Thanks for the interview + question about next steps

steps.title: Indicate that you have more information to share.
steps.content: Indicate that you have more information to share. Are there any details you didn’t get to talk about during the interview? If so, you can try sharing them in your thank you email instead. This can give you some extra space to show your interviewer why you’re a great fit for the job; you could send them some specific work samples, for example, or answer a question you didn’t fully get to in the interview. [6] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source Sample email subject lines: Thank you for the interview! Here’s the requested work sample. Thanks for meeting me + Another thing I wanted to mention!

steps.title: Compliment the interviewer in some way.
steps.content: Compliment the interviewer in some way. It’s never a bad idea to recognize their professional skills or expertise. A thoughtful compliment can help build your relationship with the interviewer and show them that you genuinely appreciated meeting them and learning a little bit about the job (and possibly the industry or specific job skills) from them. Sample email subject lines: Thank you for your guidance and valuable insights! Grateful for your advice on breaking into the industry Thanks for sharing your passion and expertise!

steps.title: Write a clear and easily understandable subject line.
steps.content: Write a clear and easily understandable subject line. No need to beat around the bush; your interviewer should know what the email is about from the subject line alone. That’s why we also recommended adding details (like the job title or date of the interview) in your subject line; the more information they have, the more easily interviewers will remember you.

steps.title: Keep your subject line concise.
steps.content: Keep your subject line concise. As important as detail is, you should also limit the length of your subject line. There’s only so much space, especially if you don’t want it to get cut off (either on a desktop or mobile phone). There’s no clear character limit since different devices and platforms have different display settings; generally, try to keep the subject line as short as possible (while still being clear and polite).

steps.title: A great subject line can get your interviewer to notice and read the email.
steps.content: A great subject line can get your interviewer to notice and read the email. As we mentioned above, hiring managers often interview a lot of people (and see even more applications) over the entire hiring process. Sending a follow-up thank you email is a great way to stand out and build rapport with them—and a polite, appreciative subject line can help the email itself stand out, too. [7] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source With a strong subject line, interviewers are more likely to recognize your name and associate you with consistent communication (and a friendly, professional attitude).

steps.title: Get right to the point.
steps.content: Get right to the point. Just like your subject line, the actual email should be brief, polite, and concise. Start with a thank you and reiterate how interested you are in the position you interviewed for. After that, you can move into the body of the email. [8] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Include a couple of brief paragraphs.
steps.content: Include a couple of brief paragraphs. In the body of your email, you can remind the interviewer of your qualifications and expertise—anything that would make you the best fit for the job. This includes key skills that were emphasized in the job description or by the interviewer, as well as contributions you hope to make if you’re hired. Here’s an outline of things to include: [9] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source Remind them why you want the job . Your thank you email should highlight your interest in the job itself, so make an effort to “sell” yourself a little. Summarize your experience . Are there any specific qualifications you want the interviewer to remember? Restate them here. Cover anything you missed before . If you have any work samples, portfolio links, or additional qualifications or experience you didn’t talk about during the interview, mention it in your email. Address any concerns . If you feel like you didn’t fully answer a question (or didn’t answer it the way you wanted to), take the opportunity to fix that by explaining your answer more clearly in the email. You can also ask any follow-up questions you didn’t think of before.

steps.title: End the email with a signature.
steps.content: End the email with a signature. When you’re ready to close your email, sign off with a professional signature, including your contact information so the interviewer knows exactly how to get in touch with you if needed. For example: Sincerely, Your Name Email: youremail@email.com Phone: 555-555-5555 Professional website (optional) LinkedIn URL or professional social media pages (optional)

steps.title: Personalize each thank-you email.
steps.content: Personalize each thank-you email. If you do several interviews and send just as many thank you emails, it might be tempting to copy and paste the same one—but resist that urge! It’s best to customize each email and mention a few details specific to the interview in question, especially if you’re emailing different people at the same company. They should feel like they got a personalized email, not a cookie-cutter one. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Subject line: Thank You! (Marketing Manager Interview)
steps.content: Subject line: Thank You! (Marketing Manager Interview) Dear Kim, Thank you for meeting with me today; I enjoyed speaking about the marketing manager position at ABCD Company. The job seems to be a great match for my skills and experience. Furthermore, the marketing strategies we discussed confirmed my desire to work with the company. I will bring over 7 years of experience in planning and organizing marketing campaigns to this role, as well as my strong leadership and market research skills. I have a proven track record of managing successful campaigns across various digital channels, and I hope to use this extensive knowledge while collaborating with the ABCD Company marketing team. I appreciate the time you took to interview me, and am very interested in working with you. I look forward to hearing from you soon. Sincerely, [Your Name]

steps.title: When do I send a thank you email after an interview?
steps.content: When do I send a thank you email after an interview? Ideally, send your email within the first 24 hours after an interview. Hiring decisions can be made pretty quickly, and thank-you emails are a key part of interview etiquette nowadays, so the sooner you send one, the better.

steps.title: Who should I send thank you emails to?
steps.content: Who should I send thank you emails to? Send an individual thank you email to everybody who interviews you throughout the process. For example, if a group of people interviews you, each person in that group should get their own (personalized) thank you email.

steps.title: Should I send a thank you email if I don’t want the job?
steps.content: Should I send a thank you email if I don’t want the job? Absolutely. Even if you’re 100% positive you don’t want the job, expressing your appreciation via email is the polite thing to do, and it can make a good impression on the hiring manager (which may help if you ever apply for a different position with the company later).

steps.title: Should I send another email if I don’t get a response to the first?
steps.content: Should I send another email if I don’t get a response to the first? Not right away, no. It can understandably cause some anxiety if you send a thank you email and don’t get a response back within the first couple of days, but resist the urge to make sure they saw it. Give it at least a week before you ask the hiring manager (or team) for an update!
